content.body: yikes - rel-logo was apparently added to the rel-registry 2011-11-24. snuck-in on last year's US Thanksgiving holiday.
I've written up the reasons why rel=logo is unnecessary and moved it to the "rejected" table in existing-rel-values: http://microformats.org/wiki/existing-rel-values#rejected
interesting that the notion of linking to a logo has been *twice* reinvented (pavatar, logo)
lol
[02:37] <josiah> What is the best way to generate a secret for a SF2 application?
[02:39] <wiistriker> drop face on keyboard
roc: you around? I wanted to ask you about something related to the HTML WG DRM video stuff
yes
roc: the chairs are planning to have a weekly telcon to discuss the DRM proposal and the other for enabling adaptive-streaming use cases
what I wanted to know is, would you be interested in calling in
my immediate reaction is "urk"
if so, there's a survey about the call time which I hope can respond to
I don't feel like I have anything to contribute beyond the policy issues we've already discussed on the list
because otherwise, the call time is likely going to be pretty bad for NZ and Australia too
heh
yeah
well, the survey is here: https://www.w3.org/2002/09/wbs/1/html-media/
in the current results, Tuesday, 1500 UTC is the time that's leading
OK
it's basically impossible to schedule a telecon that works for both Europe and me
so if I don't absolutely need to be on it, better that I'm not
I see
2100 UTC would work if Europe participants were willing to call in at 11pm
(it is possible, but it's never fun)
the thing is, what always ends up happening if we do have a telcon is that the New Zealand and Australia and Asia people always get the short end of the stick as far as call times
yep
yeah, I hear you
small price to pay for the privilege of living here, I say :-)
indeed
I'd love to visit there some time
if people wonder whether some specific proposal would meet with my approval, of course I can answer that via email or even dial in to a particular meeting if necessary
OK
I'll make an effort personally to give you a heads-up if there's anything on the calls that seems worth alerting you about
also, I guess the call time is likely to end up amenable to hsivonen being able to call in -- though I'm not sure he'll want to
I know I don't want to..
heh
https://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=17151 isn't this something for the encoding standard?
zcorpan: maybe - which spec defines other types of UTF-16 encoding errors, such as unpaired surrogates, nulls, etc?
oh, this is the case of unpaired surrogate
seems the encoding standard already does "emit a decoder error" for lone surrogates, which for HTML means U+FFFD
(and for XML means fatal error)
TabAtkins: should css3-syntax U+FFFD surrogates in escapes?
https://twitter.com/awbjs/status/204962858113564672 didn't [tm] do that
also, cool how twitter now lets you copy permanent URLs and they don't include the hash bang nonsense
nice
so the differences is that it's a normative copy http://ecma-international.org/ecma-262/5.1/

ah thanks
if you do a Google search for Java FactoryFactory you will find lots of real cases of factory factory classes
I'm afraid of following facebook.com URLs in case they never heard about GET not having side effects
I'm glad we don't have factories
the "though you may also have to deploy a few configuration files to make it all work" is the funniest part
the follow up is great too
"Luckily, 70% of the workers in the Tool-Oriented Metafactory Union are certified against this version of the spec."
that is why I write all my web apps in bash
kind of sad even new drafts such as http://people.mozilla.org/~bbirtles/web-animations/web-animations.html format everything per the old DOM standards...
and thereby define things in a crappy way, e.g. http://people.mozilla.org/~bbirtles/web-animations/web-animations.html#widl-TimedTemplate-animate-TimedItem-Element-target-float-startTime
oh, it doesn't even use RFC 2119
*sigh*
hmmm
it has "must" in notes
"must" in at least one conformance requirement
and then a colored small-caps MUST in another place
Tell this to the people writing the spec, perhaps :)
so it's actually much worse than not using RFC2119
so far, the proposed API seems kinda bad too, not just the spec
so not yet worth investing energy in
do we have a wiki with guidelines about how to write conformance requirements correctly and how to format specs in a good way?
s//page/
it seems this comes up time and time again with "new" editors
having new editors is awesome; having specs that suck is not :-)
this spec has at least a couple of non-new editors
http://wiki.whatwg.org/wiki/How_to_write_a_spec
We have http://ln.hixie.ch/?start=1140242962&count=1 ofc
oh, that one is also good, too bad it's not in that whatwg wiki page
I always wonder why people haven't read existing specs...
e.g. if you have read HTML, XMLHttpRequest, DOM, ... you should know the problems
but I guess my expectations don't meet reality, so we should indeed have some kind of wiki or document explaining that
and tell everyone "you're awesome, but take a look at <URL>"
expanded a bit on rfc2119 usage
annevk: "haven't read existing specs"? well, depends on which specs
there are tons of different specs
HTML, XHR, DOM use similar style
and have their problems
smaug____: everyone writing APIs should be at least familiar with DOM/HTML/IDL imo
DOM/IDL yes,
and some HTML
reading and understanding full HTML...
no one does that :)

annevk: are you expecting people to just be generally familiar with those technologies, or to understand in depth how they are specced, why they are specced that way, what problems you could run into building on their specs, etc?

othermaciej: I expect them to see that the way they define methods is radically different (and has holes); I expect them to look for patterns in existing methods with respect to exception handling, event dispatching, etc.
othermaciej: my expectations however seem unrealistic
e.g. quite some specs that clearly require use of the event loop don't use it
(some started using it after it being pointed out)
http://wiki.whatwg.org/wiki/How_to_write_a_spec doesn't mention the event loop
many people writing web platform specs are not expects on other web platform specs or necessarily even the other relevant technologies at all
or in some cases, not even familiar with what a spec is
maybe the respec tool should have a "read this before use" sticker
annevk: email your gripes to Brian, I'm sure he'll take them on board
zcorpan: I guess we should expand that wiki page with "Patterns" of some kind; examples of how to do various things
zcorpan: including dispatching events asynchronously
annevk: sounds like a good idea
annevk: also explicitly say that the old DOM specs is a bad pattern and why it is
annevk: it could point to real-world examples in actual specs and discuss what it does
hmm, why is the From-Origin spec stalled?
roc: I updated it yesterday to include a reason
roc: it doesn't mean much though, if people want to implement it, I'll keep updating it and we'll go back to REC-track

roc: http://dvcs.w3.org/hg/from-origin/raw-file/tip/Overview.html
roc: TR/ is never up-to-date
sorry, I couldn't find the real version :-)

TR/ will be updated next week with http://dvcs.w3.org/hg/from-origin/raw-file/tip/TR.html fwiw

MikeSmith: Really I would rather there were not any openmath special cases in the schema.  I'd prefer that the attribute value be open as it says in the spec, but if  you/heri think that's too risky and just want to allow mathml/svg/html in teh annotations I'll just grumble and not inline the openmath bits in that version of the spec
but in the case of SVG, we have it that way to make sure the people realize we're not supporting SVG 1.2
hmm, am I confident enough that MutationObserver is a good API and that the implementation is good enough for un-prefixing...
apply usual typo correction, especially to Henri's name
david_carlisle: yeah, I think it's better not to make it open and I think Henri still thinks so as well. We don't leave anything open anywhere else like that.
smaug____: no, but if you don't start unprefixing we'll never get rid of the much worse thing
true
MikeSmith: I think it;'s a mistake but I'm not going to argue just grumble:-) but as I said either way it shouldn't special case openmath
OK
because people who want to use ChemML (say) should be able to look what I did for OpenMath and I don't want them to find that what you have to do is mail you and Henri and ask to be whitelisted
david_carlisle: ah yeah
so I will yank the openmath stuff

no problem

yeah so each Document has a Window
but each browsing context (e.g. <iframe>) has a WindowProxy

annevk: ok, so it’s still safe to rely on global `this === window`, as it will always be the case; be it through a Window or a WindowProxy
phew
this === windows is always true, but window and this don't always refer to the ES global object (instead they both refer to the WindowProxy)
zcorpan: When do they refer to different things?
gsnedders: navigation
But when do you have a global existing after a navigation?
not an ES global, but you can still have a reference to a WindowProxy object
it just proxies to a different ES global
say you have an iframe, the parent saves a reference to its window, then it navigates
hmm, is this===window when doing document.open()
tests

dglazkov: Anyway afaict the tradeoff between respec and anolis is that people prefer writing specs using respec, presumably due to the lack of a compile step, but it encourages a worse style of spec writing and has a worse user experience (due to scripts running when the document loads)
jgraham: You could always set up respec to build for each commit
Instead of only doing it for TR
gsnedders: Then it would have a compile step
jgraham: But eliminating that for actual work before you commit is probably the big gain anyway.
You can automate it through commit hooks to get all the gain for no effort.
gsnedders: For what?

btw
the stuff about layout
that does not actually apply to media queries afaik
the whole point about media queries is that they don't depend on layout
the font-size preference from the user (defaulting to 16px) is known way before layout
and that's the only font-size 'em' in media queries depends upon
same for 'rem'
and 'ex', etc.

Tony Wilson style

oh, Harry Potter.  :|
speaking of Ron Weasley, how do we define HTML interfaces from JavaScript perspective? For example, what is the distinction between HTMLElement and any object that implements this interface?
magic hosted objects aside
testability?
both document.createElement('div') and window.HTMLDivElement are just objects that have HTMLElement in their prototype chain
document.createElement('div') creates an element with HTMLDivElement as its prototype.
window.HTMLDivElement.prototype that is
HTMLDivElement has HTMLElement in its prototype.
right. But from JS perspective, they are really not special in any way. There's no such thing as an "interface" in JS. So how do we get around this in DOM specs?
What do you mean, get around this in DOM specs?
What are you trying to do?
darn it, gotta run
bbiab
dglazkov: Something is an "interface" if it doesn't have a constructor.
